The Sexual Assault Prosecution Act of 2002, also known as the Sexual Offense Limitation Act, amends Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code to allow for indictments for offenses committed in violation of chapter 109A without any time limitation. Awards to states are provided to reduce DNA casework backlog. The Sexual Assault Prosecution Act of 2002 allows for indictments without time limitation for offenses under chapter 109A. Awards are granted to states to reduce DNA casework backlog by expediting analysis of unsolved crimes. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in coordination with the Assistant Attorney General, develops criteria for granting awards to states for DNA analysis of unsolved crimes. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in coordination with the Assistant Attorney General, develops criteria for granting awards to states for DNA analysis of unsolved crimes. States receiving awards must ensure that DNA laboratories meet quality assurance standards and use state-of-the-art testing methods set by the FBI. The DNA samples collected can only be accessed by criminal justice agencies, used in judicial proceedings, provided to criminal defendants for defense purposes, or used for population statistics and research purposes after removing personally identifiable information. The Department of Justice is authorized to appropriate $15,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006 for awards under this section, requiring 15 percent of the award to be spent on DNA analysis of unsolved crimes.
